Award.AwardTitle: Interface Physics and Device Technologies of Carbon-Nanostructure-Enabled Vertical Heterojunction Devices

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to advance the fundamental understanding and further develop new device architectures based on the use of low dimensional carbons (nanotubes, graphene) as electronically gated contact electrodes. The PIs have already demonstrated new devices exploiting the phenomenon. Specifically, a new architecture transistor that overcomes the inherent mobility limitations of organic semiconductors and a solar cell having a power conversion efficiency that can be dramatically improved by electronic gating.

The intellectual merit is in the promise to 1) deepen the theoretical understanding of the phenomenon by developing a comprehensive model that captures essential physics of low-dimensional-carbon-contacts and related vertical devices, 2) provide design rules for exploiting this property in devices that establish the benefits and the limits, and 3) expand the range of the devices in new directions and from individual components to functional circuits (e.g. inverters, logic gates, ring oscillator).


Broader impacts: organic semiconductors have physical limitations that bound the range of what they can do. The transformative aspect of this project is that the devices to be developed will greatly extend that range allowing for faster, higher density, plastic electronic circuits, brighter, more energy efficient displays, and higher efficiency solar cells. The educational and outreach activities will include translating the research progress to the undergraduate and graduate course materials, developing a web-based learning module, supervising minority and female student research through the outreach programs in University of Florida, and providing early exposure of K-12 students to electronics technology through the Student Science Training Program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Materials have a property, called the Fermi level, which characterizes the energy needed to extract electrons from them. When a conventional metal contacts a semiconductor, because the electrons in whichever material has the higher Fermi level can lower their energy by transferring to the lower energy Fermi level side, they spontaneously do so. That transferred charge can result in an electrostatic potential at the so called Schottky junction between the two, which provides the basis for the one way current transport in Schottky diodes (widely used electronic components) and for the charge separation occurring in Schottky junction solar cells. Now, unlike conventional metals, nano-scale carbons, like carbon nanotubes or graphene, possess Fermi levels that are readily shifted if they are charged by a near lying (so called gate) electrode, when a gate voltage is applied between the two.

In previous work the investigators realized that by gate voltage shifting the Fermi level of a nano-carbon that contacts a semiconductor the resulting change in the Schottky junction characteristics could be exploited to increase the power conversion efficiency in carbon nanotube/silicon Schottky junction solar cells and to provide a new mechanism for transconductance. The latter is what makes transistors useful, and was demonstrated in a novel carbon nanotube/organic-semiconductor vertical field effect transistor.

The goals in the present award were to take advantage of these gate field tunable nanotube/semiconductor junctions in electronic and electro-optic device, to push the limits of the device performance attainable, and to obtain, via theory and modeling, a detailed understanding of the phenomena involved. Two new types of devices were fabricated and tested.

An important figure of merit for solar cells is the power conversion efficiency (PCE) which measures the ratio of electrical energy output per second to the light energy impinging on the cell per second. As a follow-on to the previous gated nanotube/silicon solar cells that attained a best gated PCE of ~11% we fabricated and optimized a gated nanotube/Si nanowire solar cell. The previous devices lost light energy by reflection from the planar Si surface. The vertical Si nanowire forest avoided most of that reflected energy loss by the multiple reflections and light trapping between the Si nanowires. This resulted in the significantly improved power conversion efficiency from 11% to 15.1%, which is in the range of what today’s consumer solar cells provide.

The second type of device made and studied was a nanotube/silicon gated field effect transistor. This was made on both n-type and p-type silicon, which makes complementary N- and P-type transistors that allow for amplifiers that minimize power consumption. Important figures of merit for transistors are the on-state/off-state current ratio, which characterizes their degree of control over the currents, and the maximum on-state current that they can deliver. These vertical architecture transistors deliver currents that scale directly with their area so the current is specified as an areal current density: current/area. The nanotube/silicon devices exhibited excellent on/off current ratios over a million for both the N- and P-type devices, with on-currents nearly 100A/cm2 for the N-type devices and over 200A/cm2 for the P-type devices, at technologically relevant voltages.

The quantitative modeling confirmed our understanding of the mechanisms underlying the operation of these transistors. The Schottky junction formed between the nanotubes and the silicon presents a barrier to electronic transport across the junction. The near lying gate electrode, designed into the architecture, allows for gate voltage control over that barrier height and width. In the off-state the gate voltage increases both the barrier height and width reducing current that crosses the junction, while in the on-state, the opposite gate voltage decreases both the barrier height and width, increasing the current crossing the junction.

That current crossing the junction can be categorized as charge that gains a thermal boost sufficient to cross over the barrier (so called thermionic emission) and charge that undergoes quantum mechanical tunneling to go through the barrier. The tunneling current depends sensitively on the barrier width. Because such barriers thin toward their apex, thermally boosted electrons (even below top of the barrier) tunnel through more readily. While thermionic emission is readily modelled by a simple expression, the more complex thermal tunneling current can only be calculated numerically. There are significant further complications (not yet modeled) that come from the random nature of the nanotube networks used in the devices. Nevertheless, there is already good qualitative agreement between the experiments and the calculated currents, which also scale properly with the parameters under experimental control. Detailed simulation capabilities for such nanoscale carbon-semiconductor junction devices were developed, enhancing our understanding of the operating principles, explaining experimental features, and providing guidance for device design optimization. The models developed will be critical to any future exploitation of this class of devices which, given their high current carrying capability, may make them useful in power control applications.
